items.title: Spice Girls
items.body:
The **Spice Girls** are a British girl group formed in 1994, consisting of [Melanie Brown](openitem:mel-b) - [wiki:Melanie Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_B "Mel B"), also known as Mel B ("Scary Spice"); [Melanie Chisholm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanie_C "Melanie C"), or Melanie C ("Sporty Spice"); [Emma Bunton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emma_Bunton "Emma Bunton") ("Baby Spice"); [Geri Halliwell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geri_Halliwell "Geri Halliwell") ("Ginger Spice"); and [Victoria Beckham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Beckham "Victoria Beckham") ("Posh Spice"). With their "[girl power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Girl_power "Girl power")" mantra, they redefined the girl-group concept by targeting a young female fanbase. They led the [teen pop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teen_pop "Teen pop") resurgence of the 1990s, were a major part of the [Cool Britannia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cool_Britannia "Cool Britannia") era, and became pop culture icons of the decade.

The group formed through auditions held by managers [Bob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Herbert_(manager) "Bob Herbert (manager)") and [Chris Herbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Herbert "Chris Herbert"), who wanted to create a girl group to compete with the British [boy bands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boy_band "Boy band") popular at the time. They signed to [Virgin Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Records "Virgin Records") and released their debut single "[Wannabe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wannabe "Wannabe")" in 1996, which reached number one on the charts of 37 countries. Their debut album, _[Spice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_(album) "Spice (album)")_ (1996), sold more than 23 million copies worldwide, becoming [the best-selling album by a female group in history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_best-selling_girl_groups#Best-selling_girl_group_albums "List of best-selling girl groups"). The follow-up, _[Spiceworld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiceworld_(album) "Spiceworld (album)")_ (1997), sold more than 14 million copies worldwide. Both albums encapsulated the group's [dance-pop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance-pop "Dance-pop") style and message of female empowerment, with vocal and songwriting contributions shared equally by the members. In 1997, a film starring the Spice Girls, _[Spice World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_World_(film) "Spice World (film)"),_ was released; it was a commercial success but received poor reviews.

In May 1998, Halliwell left the Spice Girls, citing exhaustion and creative differences. The group carried on as a four-piece with the 1998 [Spiceworld Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiceworld_Tour "Spiceworld Tour"), which was attended by an estimated 2.1 million people to become the highest-grossing concert tour by a female group. _[Forever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forever_(Spice_Girls_album) "Forever (Spice Girls album)")_ (2000), the only Spice Girls album without Halliwell, achieved weaker sales. At the end of 2000, the Spice Girls entered a hiatus to concentrate on their solo careers. They reunited for two concert tours, [the Return of the Spice Girls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Return_of_the_Spice_Girls_Tour "The Return of the Spice Girls Tour") (2007–2008) and [Spice World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_World_%E2%80%93_2019_Tour "Spice World – 2019 Tour") (2019), both of which won the [_Billboard_ Live Music Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billboard_Live_Music_Awards "Billboard Live Music Awards") for highest-grossing engagements, making them the top touring all-female group from 2000 to 2020. _[Viva Forever!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viva_Forever!_(musical) "Viva Forever! (musical)")_, a musical based on the Spice Girls' music, opened in 2012; it was a critical and commercial failure and closed in 2013.

More at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_Girls
items.source: Remixed excerpt from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_Girls licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/).

items.title: Melanie Brown (Mel B)
items.body:
**Melanie Janine Brown** [MBE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire "Order of the British Empire") (born 29 May 1975; known as **Melanie B** and **Mel B**) is an English singer, actress, and television personality. She rose to fame in the 1990s as a member of the girl group [Spice Girls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice_Girls "Spice Girls"), in which she was nicknamed **Scary Spice**. With over 100 million records sold worldwide, the group became the [best-selling female group of all time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_best-selling_girl_groups "List of best-selling girl groups").

During the Spice Girls hiatus, Mel B released her debut solo album, _[Hot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_(Mel_B_album) "Hot (Mel B album)")_ (2000). The album's lead single, "[I Want You Back](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Want_You_Back_(Mel_B_song) "I Want You Back (Mel B song)")", reached number one on the [UK Singles Chart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"), and was included on the soundtrack for the 1998 film _[Why Do Fools Fall in Love](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Why_Do_Fools_Fall_in_Love_(film) "Why Do Fools Fall in Love (film)")_. Other singles from the album, such as "[Tell Me](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tell_Me_(Mel_B_song) "Tell Me (Mel B song)")" and "[Feels So Good](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feels_So_Good_(Mel_B_song) "Feels So Good (Mel B song)")", both reached the top 5 in the UK charts. After signing with the [independent label](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_record_label "Independent record label") Amber Café, she released her second solo album, _[L.A. State of Mind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L.A._State_of_Mind "L.A. State of Mind")_ (2005), which spawned a single, "[Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Today_(Mel_B_song) "Today (Mel B song)")". Mel B released "[For Once in My Life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_Once_in_My_Life_(Mel_B_song) "For Once in My Life (Mel B song)")" in 2013, her first single in eight years; it peaked at No. 2 on the [_Billboard_ Hot Dance Club Songs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance_Club_Songs "Dance Club Songs") chart.

More at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_B
items.source: Remixed excerpt from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_B licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/).

items.title: Tesla Model S
items.body:
The **Tesla Model S** is a [battery-powered](openitem:battery-powered) - [wiki:battery-powered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle "Battery electric vehicle") [liftback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liftback "Liftback") car produced by [Tesla, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") It was introduced on June 22, 2012, and is positioned as Tesla's flagship model.

In 2013, the Model S became the first electric car to top the monthly new-car-sales ranking in any country, leading twice in Norway, in September and December 2013 and in Denmark in December 2015. Sales passed 250,000 units in September 2018. The Model S was the top-selling [plug-in electric car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car "Plug-in electric car") worldwide in 2015 and 2016, although it was later surpassed by the [Model 3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Model_3 "Tesla Model 3").

In an early review of the Model S, _[Consumer Reports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_Reports "Consumer Reports")_ declared, "This car performs better than anything we've ever tested before. Let me repeat that: Not just the best _electric_ car, but the best car. It does just about everything really, really well." In their Owner Satisfaction survey owners have consistently rated Teslas at, or near, the top rankings. In 2019, _[Motor Trend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_Trend "Motor Trend")_ named the 2013 Tesla Model S the ultimate "Car of the Year" over the magazine's entire 70-year history. It received a refresh in June 2021.

See more https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Model_S
items.source: Remixed excerpt from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Model_S licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/).

items.title: Battery electric vehicle
items.body:
A **battery electric vehicle** (**BEV**), **pure electric vehicle**, **only-electric vehicle**, **fully electric vehicle** or **all-electric vehicle** is a type of [electric vehicle](/wiki/Electric_vehicle "Electric vehicle") (EV) that exclusively uses [chemical energy](/wiki/Chemical_energy "Chemical energy") stored in [rechargeable battery](/wiki/Rechargeable_battery "Rechargeable battery") [packs](/wiki/Battery_pack "Battery pack"), with no secondary source of propulsion (e.g. hydrogen fuel cell, internal combustion engine, etc.). BEVs use [electric motors](/wiki/Electric_motor "Electric motor") and [motor controllers](/wiki/Motor_controller "Motor controller") instead of [internal combustion engines](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine") (ICEs) for propulsion. They derive all power from battery packs and thus have no internal combustion engine, [fuel cell](/wiki/Fuel_cell "Fuel cell"), or [fuel tank](/wiki/Fuel_tank "Fuel tank"). BEVs include – but are not limited to – motorcycles, bicycles, scooters, skateboards, railcars, watercraft, forklifts, buses, trucks, and cars.

In 2016, there were 210 million electric bikes worldwide used daily. Cumulative global sales of highway-capable light-duty pure electric car vehicles passed the one million unit milestone in September 2016. As of October 2020[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Battery_electric_vehicle&action=edit), the world's top selling all-electric car in history is the [Tesla Model 3](/wiki/Tesla_Model_3 "Tesla Model 3"), with an estimated 645,000 sales, followed by the [Nissan Leaf](/wiki/Nissan_Leaf "Nissan Leaf") with over 500,000 sales as of September 2020[update](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Battery_electric_vehicle&action=edit).

See more https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle
items.source: Remixed excerpt from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/).
